column1: Bought from seller OEMGenuine. All things are fine regarding Seller and Condition. I would purchase another Laptop from OEMGenuine if I needed to.The Laptop itself is bad. Thinkpad E14 model.There is no CD/DVD Drive
column2: you have to buy an external One if you want to do something as basic as watch DVDs on it now. I guess Computer Manufacturers have decided for Us that "nobody wants that anymore."There is no Number Pad. Some people don't care about Number pads
column3: but this Laptop doesn't even give you the Option to ignore it. There just isn't One! You will have to buy an external Number Pad if you want One.There are bright white LED Indicators for Key Locks
column4: and also for the Power Button
column5: and they cannot be disabled. When the Laptop is in Sleep Mode it will slowly pulse its white Light and illuminate the whole Room at Night. Only the Laptop can sleep through this. The LEDs are eyesores even with normal usage. White is an inappropriate color for an LED Indicator on a Laptop.The keyboard has chiclet style Keys in an "island style"
column6: so they're built into a plastic Frame with individual gaps for each Key
column7: and the Keys rise out of the Gaps. Proponents of this Keyboard Style sometimes say that it helps keep Debris from getting under the Keys. But they are wrong. Debris will get into the Keys unless you are Computing in a Sterile Laboratory
column8: and when Debris does get under one of the Keys you can't pry the Key up to remove the Debris even a little bit
column9: and you can't shoot compressed Air underneath the Key to dislodge it. You will just have to mash the key around and try to crunch the Debris into slightly less intrusive Grit. (Bear in mind that we suggest NOT removing the Keys manually for cleaning - Chiclet Key Retainers love to break when lifted from Above.)Very poor design Decisions made for such an expensive Laptop. It used to be that spending more Money would get you more or better Features. Now it just buys sharper Build Quality and prestigious Brand Name.

column4: and 32GB of RAM was my goal.  Even in a matter of a day

column6: as I reinstalled Windows on an NVMe SSD in the m.2 slot near the standard SATA III SSD
column7: which acts as storage in my setup.  I've never had a more potent or quieter laptop!The 14" display is a perfect size for me
column8: and having the ThinkShutter to block the camera is a big help in terms of privacy.Longevity and durability is always a waiting game
column9: but I believe in how well this PC was crafted.  I recommend this ThinkPad E14 i7/32GB RAM/1 TB SSD setup wholeheartedly.

column1: I was looking for a relatively quiet (low fan noise) laptop that had enough power to run some occasionally heavy load software like simulators or compilers. I also didn't want to pay for a touch screen which I know I'll never use. I detest finger prints on the screen. Although not the fastest machine on the market
column2: this 15W  I5 processor allows the machine to quickly chew through many tough applications and do it quietly. It was delivered ahead of the original estimate and arrived in perfect condition. I'm very happy with the power and size of this machine and would recommend it to anyone looking for a small quiet laptop that looks like it's built to last.

column1: I have owned this laptop for over a year and use it everyday for work. This is an excellent machine for typical business users. The machine has plenty of CPU power
column2: memory
column3: and disk for my needs. It boots Windows 10 fast and I have had zero hardware problems. I really like the Battery Charge Threshold feature. This sets the maximum charge on the battery to 80% which prolongs battery life (not runtime) if the laptop is mostly used while plugged into AC. The screen is clear and crisp. We have kids in college and this is my 4th Lenovo laptop purchase. I have a gaming rig desktop so I cannot say if it runs games but it does run Roblox just fine.

column1: these come with USA power adaptors!  so not useful in AUS
The Lenovo ThinkPad E14 is an office laptop
column2: which is not as slim as the devices from the X-series and there are not as many features as on the T-series
column3: but the laptops often cost only half the price and they offer all the important things you need to work. Lenovo also fixes one major complaint and equips the new ThinkPad E14 G3 with brighter displays and there is also an optional screen with 100% sRGB coverage.

column1: Lenovo did not change the chassis and the black design might appear a bit boring
column2: but it is definitely functional. You can notice the low price in terms of materials because you get a combination of plastic and aluminum (lid and bottom panel). The stability is still good and you cannot twist or dent the base unit (no creaking sounds). The lid itself is also sturdy
column3: but we can quickly provoke picture distortions with concentrated pressure on the back and twisting attempts. The hinges are well adjusted and there is only minor bouncing.

column1: The E14 G3 is the heaviest and largest device in our comparison group; it is noticeably deeper in terms of footprint. The USB-C power adapter tips the scale at around 360 grams.
The port situation is still the same
column2: even though we would appreciate some updates. You get a USB-C port including charging functionality as well as DisplayPort and a full-size HDMI output
column3: but a slow USB 2.0 port is not really appropriate for a laptop in 2021. More expensive ThinkPad models (like the T-series) definitely have an advantage in this regard.

column1: Lenovo uses a Wi-Fi 6 module from RealTek
column2: but the transfer rates are lower compared to
column3: which was equipped with the Intel AX200. It is now a 1x1 module (160 MHz) with a maximum transfer rate of 866 Mbps. The signal quality was always good during our review period. The E14 G3 also offers a Gigabit Ethernet port
column4: but there are no WWAN modules available.

column1: As expected
column2: you only get a simple 720p webcam (0.9 MP) with a mechanical shutter (ThinkShutter)
column3: which takes pretty bad pictures. There is also an IR camera for facial recognition via Windows Hello.

column1: Similar to previous ThinkPad E laptops
column2: you can remove the whole bottom cover
column3: but the process is not simple. The panel is still extremely tight after you have removed all the screws and there are plenty of plastic clips that can break easily. Other ThinkPad models are much easier to open.

column1: The warranty once again shows the entry-level position of the ThinkPad E14
column2: because our test unit only comes with a one-year warranty. You can still extend the duration for an additional price. Some models of the E14 are also sold with a two-year warranty.

column1: The ThinkPad E14 G3 still gets the familiar and excellent keyboard with 1.8 mm travel and rich feedback. Despite the low price
column2: the E14 has a big advantage over much more expensive ThinkPad X models
column3: which are now equipped with shallower and flatter keyboards. You will definitely be happy when you write a lot and the E14 G3 also comes with a two-stage background illumination.

column1: The displays have always been a problem of the inexpensive ThinkPad E14-series. The picture quality was okay for an office laptop
column2: but the brightness was hardly competitive at around 250 nits. Lenovo now improved the situation
column3: and our test unit is the default IPS screen with an advertised brightness of 300 nits
column4: and our test unit even manages 330 nits. There is also an optional panel with full sRGB coverage if you want to edit pictures. Some regions also get an inexpensive TN panel with a brightness of 250 nits
column5: but we would not recommend this option.

column1: We analyzed the display with the professional CalMAN software and the grayscale is already very accurate out of the box. There is only a minor blue cast
column2: but it is not visible with the naked eye. The colors on the other hand clearly show that it is an inexpensive IPS screen with limited color gamut (~60% sRGB) and we can see huge deviations compared to the sRGB reference color space.

column1: We calibrated the panel (X-Rite i1 Pro 2) and the corresponding profile can be downloaded in the box above. The grayscale improved a bit
column2: but the colors still show high deviations.

column1: The additional brightness is definitely appreciated outdoors and you have a little bit more headroom
column2: but you should still get a place in the shade for the most comfortable viewing experience.

column1: Our review unit is equipped with the¬†¬†with 6 cores (12 threads) and a maximum clock of 4 GHZ. More technical information about the CPU is available¬†.

The new ThinkPad E14 beats the rivals in multi-core benchmarks. Tiger Lake based laptops are much slower and even the 45W processor¬†¬†in the¬†¬†is slower than the AMD chip. If you only stress one core
column2: however
column3: the Intel chips have an advantage. We should mention that Intel CPUs often benefit from high power limits for short peak load
column4: which is not the case for the AMD chip in the E14. The performance is not reduced on battery power.

column1: Talking about the overall system performance
column2: the new ThinkPad E14 G3 leaves a great impression. The results in the synthetic benchmarks confirm our subjective impression; the device executes inputs very quickly and there are no bottlenecks in the system configuration. You can expand the memory up to 40 GB (8 GB onboard + 1 RAM slot up to 32 GB).

column1: Our standardized latency test (web browsing
column2: YouTube 4K playback
column3: CPU load) shows increased latencies for the ThinkPad E14 G3
column4: so there can be problems when you use real-time audio applications.

column1: The ThinkPad E14 G3 has two SSD slots. Our review unit was equipped with a compact M.2-2242 module from SK Hynix (BC711) and a storage capacity of 512 GB (435 GB free after initial set-up). Both drives are attached via PCIe-3.0 x4 and the transfer rates are good. Thanks to the empty M.2-2280 slot
column2: it is very easy to upgrade the storage capacity if necessary. More SSD benchmarks can be found .

column1: The Ryzen 5 5500U is equipped with the integrated Radeon RX Vega 7
column2: which is basically the old¬†¬†we already know from Ryzen 4000 chips. More technical information about the iGPU is available¬†. This is also the case for the performance
column3: which benefits from the dual-channel memory configuration
column4: but it is on the expected level in general. Intel's integrated¬†
column5: which is also available in the Intel model of the¬†
column6: for example
column7: is a bit faster in the synthetic benchmarks.

column1: The difference between the Vega 7 and the Iris Xe Graphics G7 (96 EUs) is much smaller in the actual gaming benchmarks. Gaming is possible on the E14 G3
column2: but you are usually limited to low or medium settings to get smooth gameplay. More gaming benchmarks with the Vega 7 are available .

column1: The new E14 G3 still uses a single fan and it is a very quiet device overall. Compared to many Intel based laptops
column2: there is no high power limit
column3: so the fan usually does not start spinning in short peak load scenarios. The noise level is still convenient when you stress the CPU and the iGPU simultaneously and there are no annoying frequencies. We did not notice any other electronic sounds like coil whine on our test unit
column4: either.

column1: The ThinkPad E14 G3 is not uncomfortable warm
column2: despite the quiet fan. We can determine almost 50 ¬∞C at the bottom during the stress test and you should not put the device on your lap in this scenario
column3: but there are no limitations in everyday situations. The fan speed is a bit lower when you play games like Witcher 3
column4: so the chassis is even a bit warmer.

column1: We can once again see that the consumption levels off at 30 Watts during the stress test. There are some fluctuations after about 10 minutes but the performance is very stable in general and there is no major drop. The processor runs at 6x 2.6-2.8 GHz and the iGPU at ~450 MHz. There is no performance reduction immediately after the stress test.

The two stereo speakers once again carry the same Harman branding and we cannot notice a difference from the previous model. The result is surprisingly good for an inexpensive office device and you can easily enjoy some videos or some background music. Conferences benefit from the good representation of high tones
column2: which is great for clear voices.

column1: Our consumption measurements show slight improvements
column2: because the idle values are comparable or even slightly better compared to the ThinkPad E14 G2 (both Intel as well as AMD)
column3: despite the brighter display. AMD system behave differently under load since there are no increased power limits for short periods
column4: so the consumption is stable. We determine up to 55W during the stress test
column5: so the compact 65W power adapter (USB-C) is completely sufficient.

column1: Lenovo increased the battery capacity to 57 Wh and this obviously has a positive effect on the battery runtime. Almost all the rivals including the two models of the ThinkPad E14 G2 (both AMD as well as Intel) are clearly beaten. Our Wi-Fi test at an adjusted brightness of 150 nits results in almost 11.5 hours and still more than 8 hours at the maximum brightness. It seems that AMD laptops with shorter battery runtime are a thing of the past. The video test benefits from the more efficient video decoder with a runtime of almost 14 hours.
The third generation of the ThinkPad E14 is once again a good office laptop with a great price-performance ratio. You do not get the most high-end specs or best materials
column2: but the notebook does not disappoint in the important sections and it is once again equipped with an excellent keyboard
column3: which is not the case anymore for many more expensive ThinkPads. The keyboard is also a big advantage compared to the rivals.

column1:
Thanks for your patience all, I got in contact with Lenovo regarding about the display dimming and here is the official word, thank you to Lenovo ANZ team for the clarification.
Lenovo response -
With respect to display brightness, it‚Äôs hardcoded in the Thinkpad E14 G2 AMD BIOS to balance battery life and performance. One component that drives battery consumption is the LCD brightness. Therefore when running in Battery mode, the display will dim to some extent to get back to a ‚Äúbalance battery life/performance‚Äù status.


However there‚Äôs a brightness adjustment in AMD Radeon settings that will enable you to manually overwrite the selection.

https://support.lenovo.com/au/en/solutions/ht510641-brightness-adjustment-in-amd-radeon-settings-thinkpad-e495-e595-e14-gen2-type-20t7-20t6-e15-gen2-type-20t920t8
thanks

column2: but a home user that likes to tinker with things like some music production and digital drawing
column3: and some legacy gaming where I don't need a majorly powerful GPU
column4: although it looks like the integrated Radeon in the Ryzen 4000 series is nothing to sneeze at either. My reason for honing in on a Thinkpad though
column5: is that I value the durability and upgradeability
column6: as I usually keep my laptops for 5 years or more
column7: plus with this E series model it doesn't really cost much more than a lot of consumer laptops with Ryzen and similar specs. I can take the "cost cutting" measures of the E series as I really don't need that many ports (nice that this still has full sized HDMI and a flip-down Ethernet jack that doesn't need a dongle though)
column8: and it also loses the 2 signature silver hinges from the L series and up
column9: but I think this one actually looks cleaner. Another reason is nostalgia. The first laptop I bought with my own money after doing odd summer jobs as a kid was a somewhat gutted IBM-made Thinkpad from circa 1997 used on eBay
column10: I forget the exact model. I found all the missing components
column15: a PCMCIA modem card (family was still on dail-up ugh) and the CD ROM drive (it had one of those hot-swappable drive bays
column16: remember those? I later got the floppy disk one too) and installed Windows XP which was current at the time
column17: and had a really decent computer for cheap. Other than a number of modern developments like thin-ness and display bezel size
column18: the basic shape and design of these newer Lenovo Thinkpads really hasn't changed all that much. I'm excited to mess around with the TouchPoint nib too
column19: as I got really good with it on my childhood Thinkpad because it only had the TouchPoint as an on-board pointing device and no touchpad. That webcam is kinda meh
column20: but looks perfectly serviceable for video calls
column21: and it looks like it has decent low light performance too. It's no worse I think that the webcams in MacBooks that cost twice as much
column22: I think they still use 720p webcams.

column2: especially if what you want is a full laptop experience. The Tab S7+ is definitely better than any tablet (WOW what a display; it is intoxicating!) I've used or seen before. column3: write letters
column4: read e-books
column5: consume any media and easily carry w/o ever being a burden is a huge value to me. I have an i9 4K Dell Precision mobile workstation with 2 TB of storage and 32 GB memory for doing real work but carrying an additional 5 lbs plus charger is a huge weight I rarely move around with. The Samsung Tab is like fun to dance anywhere with. Light weight DOES have its advantages!

model is around 60.05 Hertz. Now the scaling  of the display by default comes around 150%.

XE graphics card, but I was actually able to  do some combos on this machine without any lag.

and run three performance tests. Now the first  one is all about the modern office battery life.

until the battery reaches around 2% and then dies.
The battery life on this test took around 7  hours and 20 minutes on my second test, I ran
video battery life and it took around 9 hours and  45 minutes. And my last test was all about gaming
and it took around 2 hours and 41 minutes average  without using PC mark ten. I was using the machine
with my editing with premiere doing some  color correction with De Vinci, resolve
play some games going online  editing some Photoshop files.
I was able to get between six and a half  to 7 hours of battery life on this machine,
